Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Synthesis of Bridged Polycyclic Natural Products via Intramolecular C-H Insertion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, supported by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Jeremy A. May of the University of Houston is developing a general method for the chemical synthesis of a variety of biologically active bridged polycyclic natural products. While such structures in the past have required disparate strategic approaches, the use of a cascade reaction sequence efficiently provides a variety of these molecules with control over the molecular bonding. Highly reactive carbene intermediates, carbon-carbon triple bonds that are covalently linked, and dimeric rhodium catalysts allow multiple chemical bonds, including highly strained cyclic structures, to be synthesized in one reaction. As the reaction sequence forms its final chemical bond through a C-H bond insertion, no prior modification of the substrate at the site of this insertion is required, which greatly increases efficiency, maximizes flexibility, and minimizes waste. The controlling elements for the reactivity are under study, and new catalysts for the transformation are being designed.

The structural motifs produced by this synthesis technology are found in numerous biologically active compounds produced naturally in minute quantities. Since these natural products display antimalarial, anticancer, antimicrobial, and other useful properties, the synthetic strategy is being applied to these targets to obtain sufficient material for further study. Moreover, the rapid nature of the chemical synthesis allows modifications to the parent structure to be made so that the key molecular elements for biological activity may be identified. Thus, this effort has a broader impact on disease mechanisms, natural product biology, and several fields of chemistry. The research effort under this award is integrated in multiple levels of education, as the graduate, undergraduate, and junior high students who participate learn principles of biochemistry, organic chemistry, medicinal chemistry, catalysis, and scientific analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical reactions that utilize high-energy intermediates allow the formation of many chemical bonds in a single process. These cascading reactions greatly increase the efficiency of chemists, as more molecular construction is possible in a single process. Carbenes are easily accessed reactive intermediates, and during the course of this grant period we made advances in their use. We also showed the reactions? utility in the synthesis of natural products of interest.

Objective 1:

The first objective was to identify new forms of carbene-based cascading reactions. We found that a hydrazone was a much safer and more easily handled precursor to the reactive carbene intermediates. The increased control over the reaction offered new reactivity options. Key insights were obtained into the reaction mechanism through the isolation of reaction intermediates and detailed control experiments, which allowed other scientists and us to innovate even more powerful and efficient chemical transformations. For example, we demonstrated that the cascade reaction would undergo additional bond-forming steps with the use of additional carbon-carbon triple bonds.

Another novel insight was the use of nitrene-initiated cascades, where a reactive nitrogen resulted ultimately in carbon-carbon bond formation. Mechanistic investigations into this process were conducted to understand the fundamental processes involved. Though initial trials produced five different products, we have now found optimal reaction parameters for the selective chemical synthesis of 3 of the 5 possible product outcomes.

The catalyst used for cascading carbene reactions is very important. Grant support was essential for developing a novel type of catalyst that has chiral biaryl bidentate ligands. These catalysts demonstrated huge potential to absolutely control the 3-dimensional structure of molecules in the cascade reaction while exceeding the special reactivity of the previously most reactive catalyst that does not fully control 3D structure. The crystal structure guided the design of future catalysts that will take advantage of the core architecture of the catalyst.

Overall, the carbene cascade reactions are now more accessible and powerful. The insights gained through this objective have had a large impact on carbene reaction development, with over a dozen groups now working on related chemical methods.

Objective 2:

The power of carbene cascade reactions was applied to the chemical synthesis of high-interest natural products (compounds produced in nature, typically in minute quantities). The core of brazilide A (from a family with highly interesting biological activity) has been synthesized. The incorporation of just one more building block will allow us to complete the synthesis. Several cascade reaction precursors were prepared for carnosol, a natural product with antibiotic and anti-cancer activities. Lastly, a synthetic approach for maoecrystal V has been explored and disclosed. This advancement will aid in understanding the generation of these compounds, provide material for testing, and demonstrate the power of the reactions that have been developed.

Educational Plan:

We established a ?Science @UH? program in collaboration with faculty at KIPP Sharpstown charter school (a fine-arts college-prep academy for disadvantaged students) so that each year ~forty grade 6?8 students visited the University of Houston campus, participate in chemistry demonstrations, tour the chemistry labs, and engage in presentations on preparing for college, professional school, and a career. We built the program to incorporate hands-on demonstrations for the students, which included ooblek (non-Newtonian fluid), electrolysis to form hydrogen filled bubbles (forms of energy), liquid nitrogen (phase changes), and making bouncy balls from the polymer derived from borax and white glue. The students had 20 minutes at each station to learn and experiment with the principles for themselves. We also invited the UH ACS student section to participate and present more hazardous (and non-interactive) chemical demonstrations. The visiting KIPP students were excited to see a group of college students as diverse as themselves perform stimulating experiments. All participants were allowed to keep the safety goggles they wore during experiments as mementos. The teacher organizers from KIPP even used the trip as motivation for the students to study and do well on their science tests. The focus at this KIPP campus is fine arts, and there is limited budget for science programs, so this collaboration has a huge impact on students? education. It also fulfills KIPP?s mission in preparing and motivating students for attending college.

            Work conducted supported by the grant has been included in 5 PhD dissertations and 2 Master?s theses. Another 5 PhD dissertations will include the above results when those graduate students graduate. Five undergraduates have also conducted research under the umbrella of this CAREER award, with 3 of them using their results to write senior theses. All of these students were supported financially from the grant either by stipend or in the purchase of supplies for their projects.
